alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.description: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing.
alerts.solution: Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate.

alerts.name: X-Frame-Options Header Not Set
alerts.description: X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against clickjacking attacks.
alerts.solution: Most modern web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it is set on all web pages returned by your site.

alerts.name: X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing
alerts.description: The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to nosniff.
alerts.solution: Ensure that the application sets the Content-Type header appropriately.

alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.description: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server - Unix.
alerts.solution: Manually confirm that the timestamp data is not sensitive, and that the data cannot be aggregated to disclose exploitable patterns.

alerts.name: Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set
alerts.description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.

alerts.name: Weak SSL/TLS Cipher Suites Detected
alerts.description: The server supports SSL/TLS cipher suites that are considered weak. These include cipher suites using RC4, DES, 3DES, or export-grade encryption. Weak ciphers can be exploited by attackers to decrypt intercepted communications.
alerts.solution: Configure the server to use only strong cipher suites. Disable RC4, DES, 3DES, and export-grade ciphers. Prefer AES-GCM and ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher suites.

alerts.name: SSL Certificate Expiring Soon
alerts.description: The SSL/TLS certificate for this site will expire within 30 days. An expired certificate will cause browsers to display security warnings and may prevent users from accessing the site.
alerts.solution: Renew the SSL/TLS certificate before it expires. Consider using automated certificate management (e.g., Let's Encrypt with auto-renewal).

alerts.name: Deprecated TLS Version Supported
alerts.description: The server supports TLS 1.0 and/or TLS 1.1, which are deprecated protocols with known security vulnerabilities. Major browsers have disabled support for these versions.
alerts.solution: Configure the server to only support TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3. Disable TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 completely.

alerts.name: Certificate Chain Incomplete
alerts.description: The SSL/TLS certificate chain is incomplete. Some browsers may not be able to verify the certificate authenticity, leading to security warnings.
alerts.solution: Ensure the server sends the complete certificate chain including all intermediate certificates. Do not include the root CA certificate.

alerts.name: Self-Signed Certificate Detected
alerts.description: The server is using a self-signed SSL/TLS certificate. Self-signed certificates are not trusted by browsers and can facilitate man-in-the-middle attacks.
alerts.solution: Obtain a certificate from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA). Consider using free CAs like Let's Encrypt for production environments.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Version Information via "Server" HTTP Response Header Field
alerts.description: The web/application server is leaking version information via the "Server" HTTP response header. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other vulnerabilities your web/application server is subject to.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress the "Server" header or provide generic details.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)
alerts.description: The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.

alerts.name: Application Error Disclosure
alerts.evidence: Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory at Object.fs.openSync
alerts.description: This page contains an error/warning message that may disclose sensitive information like the location of the file that produced the unhandled exception. This information can be used to launch further attacks against the web application.
alerts.solution: Review the source code of this page. Implement custom error pages. Consider implementing a mechanism to provide a unique error reference/identifier to the client while logging the details on the server side.

alerts.name: Stack Trace Disclosure
alerts.description: A stack trace was disclosed in the HTTP response body. Stack traces can reveal implementation details and potential code paths that attackers can use to identify vulnerabilities.
alerts.solution: Configure the application to not display stack traces in production. Implement proper error handling that logs errors server-side while showing generic error messages to users.

alerts.name: Sensitive Information in URL
alerts.description: Sensitive information such as credentials, API keys, or session tokens appears to be passed in the URL. URLs may be logged by browsers, proxies, and web servers, potentially exposing this data.
alerts.solution: Do not pass sensitive information in URLs. Use POST methods with request bodies, or HTTP headers for authentication tokens.

alerts.name: Private IP Disclosure
alerts.description: A private IP address such as 10.x.x.x, 172.x.x.x, 192.168.x.x was found in the HTTP response body. This information might be useful to an attacker for targeting internal systems.
alerts.solution: Remove the private IP address from the HTTP response body. For comments, use access control to limit access to private network information.

alerts.name: Email Address Disclosure
alerts.description: Email addresses were disclosed in the HTTP response. Email addresses can be used for social engineering attacks, spam, and targeted phishing.
alerts.solution: Consider obfuscating email addresses on public-facing pages or use contact forms instead of displaying email addresses directly.

alerts.name: Credit Card Number Disclosure
alerts.description: A credit card number was found in the HTTP response. This is a serious data breach that violates PCI-DSS requirements.
alerts.solution: Immediately investigate and remove credit card numbers from responses. Ensure proper data handling and never return full card numbers. Use tokenization.

alerts.name: Cross Site Scripting (Reflected)
alerts.description: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) is an attack technique that involves echoing attacker-supplied code into a user's browser instance.
alerts.solution: Phase: Architecture and Design - Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur.

alerts.name: Cross Site Scripting (Persistent)
alerts.description: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) is an attack technique that involves echoing attacker-supplied code into a user's browser instance.
alerts.solution: Phase: Architecture and Design - Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur.

alerts.name: SQL Injection
alerts.description: SQL injection may be possible.
alerts.solution: Do not trust client side input, even if there is client side validation in place.

alerts.name: Remote OS Command Injection
alerts.description: Attack technique used for unauthorized execution of operating system commands.
alerts.solution: If possible, use library calls rather than external processes to recreate the desired functionality.

alerts.name: Server Side Code Injection
alerts.description: A code injection vulnerability exists when user controllable input is evaluated at runtime.
alerts.solution: Do not trust client side input, and use proper output encoding.

alerts.name: LDAP Injection
alerts.description: LDAP Injection may be possible. It may be possible to bypass authentication or access unauthorized data.
alerts.solution: Validate and sanitize all user input. Use parameterized LDAP queries instead of string concatenation.

alerts.name: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR)
alerts.evidence: Successfully accessed data belonging to user 456 while authenticated as user 123
alerts.description: The application appears to allow access to objects by manipulating a predictable identifier in the URL or request parameters. An attacker could access resources belonging to other users by changing the ID value.
alerts.solution: Implement proper access control checks that verify the requesting user has permission to access the requested resource. Use unpredictable identifiers (UUIDs) instead of sequential IDs where possible.

alerts.name: Horizontal Privilege Escalation
alerts.attack: Accessed another user's account data by changing account_id parameter
alerts.evidence: Response contains data for account_id=789 when authenticated user owns account_id=123
alerts.description: The application allows a user to access resources or perform actions that should only be available to other users at the same privilege level. This is a form of broken access control.
alerts.solution: Implement row-level security checks to ensure users can only access their own resources. Verify ownership or permission before returning sensitive data.

alerts.name: Vertical Privilege Escalation
alerts.evidence: Admin endpoint returned data when accessed by non-admin user
alerts.description: The application allows a regular user to access functionality that should only be available to administrators or higher-privileged users.
alerts.solution: Implement role-based access control (RBAC) and verify user roles server-side before allowing access to privileged operations.

alerts.name: Missing Function Level Access Control
alerts.evidence: Successfully invoked privileged function without admin role
alerts.description: Critical application functions are not properly protected. Attackers can forge requests to access functionality without proper authorization.
alerts.solution: Implement consistent access control checks for all functions. Deny by default and explicitly grant access based on user roles and permissions.

alerts.name: Forced Browsing to Restricted Resources
alerts.description: The application does not properly restrict access to sensitive URLs, files, or directories. An attacker can directly access restricted resources by guessing or discovering their URLs.
alerts.solution: Implement proper access controls on all sensitive resources. Do not rely on obscurity for security. Use authentication and authorization checks consistently.
